comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: "N.Y. May Day Parade Strikers' children from Paterson.", it reads. This relates to the Paterson Silk Strike of 1913, and this therefore is of course May 01, 1913. Here is a reference in a book to the New York May Day Parade of 1913: books.google.com.au/books?id=8oXpyXXavIkC&pg=PA79&... Here's the wikipedia entry on the strike: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paterson_Silk_Strike_of_1913 And from the New York Times of May 02, 1913: " It was a strikeless May Day for New York, and the paraders had to import some 110 children of Paterson silk strikers from New Jersey to give embodiment to the woes of the workers." and "The big auto labeled "Children of Paterson Strikers" in great red letters reached Union Square at 4:10 o'clock, and was greeted with the greatest burst of cheering of the day." [ ref. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9505E7DB103BE633A... ] I don't know if this photograph was taken in Union Square. Perhaps some of you New Yorkers can help with that one.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: By comparison with the newly uploaded photograph [ www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3295494976/ ] which was taken in Union Square on May Day 1913, we can now say that this photograph too was taken when the Stirkers' children arrived in Union Square. I'm tagging this and some other associated photographs with "May Day 1913" to make them easier to find.

comment.author: 34876228@N04
comment._content: Thank you for this information. We'll correct the source data for the two photographs and reload the descriptions.
